questions.text: A new IT employee is feeling guilty, miserable, and unable to concentrate on his task. His symptoms began three years ago, when he began college. The following is the most likely diagnosis: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysthymia

 

The patient's symptoms of guilt, misery, and concentration issues lasting three years are indicative of dysthymia (Persistent Depressive Disorder).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depressive disorder: At least 5 out of 9 symptoms should be present to diagnose depressive disorders which include: sad mood, loss of interest, guilt or worthlessness, lack of energy, poor concentration, increased or decreased appetite, increased or decreased psychomotor activity, increased or decreased sleep, and suicidal thoughts. The patient described above has only two of the above three symptoms. Patients with dysthymia have lesser symptoms and also the social occupational dysfunction is lesser in comparison to depressive disorder.

 

Option C. Adjustment disorder: It is characterized by emotional responses to stressful situations such as financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems etc. The symptoms range from anxiety to depressive symptoms. Symptoms usually last no longer than six months after removal of the stressor

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: It is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which fluctuations between hypomania and mild depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania/hypomania or depression. The above described features do not mention any hypomanic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysthymia is characterized by chronic, less severe depressive symptoms lasting at least two years. Symptoms should not even be severe enough to meet the criteria of mild depressive disorder. (Subsyndromal depression >2 years duration). If the depressive disorder continues for more than 2 years, it is known as chronic depression.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: A husband and wife presented to the outpatient department with complaints of the husband's premature ejaculation, which is leading to frequent conflicts between them. Which of the following non-pharmacological techniques is most appropriate for treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze Technique

 

For the management of premature ejaculation, the Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method that is often recommended. This technique involves sexual stimulation until the individual is close to ejaculation. At that point, the partner squeezes the shaft of the penis (coronal ridge of glans) for several seconds, which can delay ejaculation. This process is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed to occur. The Squeeze Technique helps in increasing the time before ejaculation and is directly targeted at managing premature ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensate Focus Technique: While this technique, which involves non-genital pleasuring, can be helpful in reducing performance anxiety and improving sexual communication, it is not specifically designed for the treatment of premature ejaculation. It is useful for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Exposure and Response Prevention: This is a technique used primarily in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder and is not typically employed for premature ejaculation.

 

Option D. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT can be useful for addressing underlying psychological issues contributing to sexual dysfunction, but it is a more general approach and not as specifically targeted for premature ejaculation as the Squeeze Technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Squeeze Technique is a specific non-pharmacological method effective in the management of premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis before the point of ejaculation to delay it and can be repeated several times to increase the time before ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 531.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Option C. Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is more challenging than the forward span and is used to assess working memory.

 

Option D. Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps: Like the serial (100-7) test, it's more of an assessment for concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The digit span forward test, which involves repeating a sequence of numbers, is a measure of immediate memory and is a fundamental aspect of cognitive assessments.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

choices.text: a, b & c

questions.text:
An elderly woman, whose home was destroyed in an earthquake, visits your office with complaints of anxiety, sadness, insomnia, anger, palpitations, and despair. Consider the following statements? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

  1. The woman is experiencing an acute stress reaction
  2. The defense mechanism involved is projection
  3. The drug of choice in this situation is risperidone
  4. She needs referral to a psychiatrist for psychotherapy

Which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. a & d

 

Explanation:


The woman is likely suffering from an acute stress reaction, which is a normal psychological response to a traumatic event, such as an earthquake. This condition is usually short-lived and resolves within a few days. The primary defense mechanism in acute stress reactions is denial, not projection, which is more commonly associated with hallucinations and delusions. Referral to a psychiatrist is important for psychological support, including psychotherapy, to help the patient process the trauma and prevent the development of long-term conditions like PTSD. While risperidone may be used if there are significant symptoms such as palpitations and sleep disturbances, it is not the first-line treatment in this scenario.

 

Other options:


Option A. a & c: Although the patient may exhibit symptoms that could be treated with medication, risperidone is not the primary treatment for acute stress reactions.
 

Option B. b & d: Projection is not the correct defense mechanism in this context, making this option incorrect.
 

Option C. a, b & c: Projection is not applicable, and risperidone is not the primary treatment, so this combination is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In cases of acute stress reaction following trauma, the focus should be on supportive care and referral for psychotherapy rather than immediate use of antipsychotic medications

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

choices.text: Start desmopressin therapy immediately
Implement behavioral therapy using a bed alarm system
Prescribe imipramine as a first-line treatment
Restrict evening fluid intake and monitor

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of persistent bed-wetting occurring about twice a week over the past year. The parents report that the child has no daytime urinary symptoms, and there is no history of urinary tract infections or other medical problems. Physical examination and urinalysis are unremarkable, ruling out any organic causes. The parents are concerned and want to know the best approach to manage this condition. What should be the appropriate treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Implement behavioral therapy using a bed alarm system

 

Explanation:

 

The first-line treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis, especially when there are no underlying organic causes, is behavioral therapy using a bed alarm system. This method, also known as bell and pad conditioning, involves placing a moisture-sensitive pad in the child’s bed, which triggers an alarm when it detects wetness. This approach conditions the child to wake up when they need to urinate and eventually learn to hold urine through the night or wake up before wetting. Bed alarms have the highest success rates and lowest relapse rates among non-pharmacologic interventions and are considered safe and effective for managing nocturnal enuresis in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start desmopressin therapy immediately: Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin, is effective in reducing urine production at night and can be used when behavioral interventions fail or are not feasible. However, it is not recommended as the first-line treatment due to potential side effects and the higher relapse rate once medication is discontinued.

 

Option C. Prescribe imipramine as a first-line treatment: Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant, can be used in refractory cases of nocturnal enuresis but is associated with significant side effects, including cardiac arrhythmias and the risk of overdose. It is not considered the first-line therapy due to its safety profile compared to behavioral approaches.

 

Option D. Restrict evening fluid intake and monitor: Restricting fluids before bedtime is a supportive measure that can help reduce bedwetting but is not effective as a standalone treatment. It should be combined with other interventions like bed alarms for the best outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis is behavioral therapy using bed alarms, which condition the child to wake up to urinate and reduce bedwetting episodes. Desmopressin and imipramine are secondary options reserved for cases where behavioral approaches fail or are not suitable.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pathological doubt

 

Pathological doubt is one of the most common symptoms in adult obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). People with OCD frequently doubt whether they've done something correctly, whether it's locking the door, turning off the stove, or other everyday tasks (obsession). This doubt leads them to repeatedly check or perform rituals to alleviate their anxiety (compulsion).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aggressive symptoms, Option B. Need for symmetry, and Option D. Sexual symptoms are also seen in OCD, but the constant doubt and resultant checking rituals are among the most characteristic and prevalent symptoms of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In adult OCD, most common presentation is obsession of contamination with compulsion of washing, followed by pathological doubt and checking rituals.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

Let's match the descriptions to the terms:

 

A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking low dose of drug

questions.text: Which of the following best describes paradoxical suicide? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

 

Paradoxical suicide refers to the situation where a patient, who has been depressed and possibly suicidal, begins to show signs of improvement or recovery and then commits suicide. This paradox may occur because as the patient starts to recover, they regain some of their energy and motivation, which they might then use to act on their previously existing suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

About 2/3rd of patients with depression have suicidal ideation and 10-15% die by suicide. Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide, this is known as Paradoxical suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 366.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

The insight scale is graded from 1 to 5. In this scenario, the patient recognizes that there's something wrong with him mentally, which signifies some level of insight. However, he attributes it to the summer season, an external factor. This corresponds to a score of 3, which is recognition of a mental illness but blaming it on external causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insight is graded from 1 to 5.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 967.

choices.text: b, c & d
a, b, c & d

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male presents with complaints of frequently checking doors even when they are locked, causing him significant distress. He is diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Consider the following statements:(AIIMS NOV 2016)

  1. Repression and reaction formation are the defense mechanisms involved
  2. SSRIs are the drug of choice
  3. Risperidone may be used in SSRI-resistant cases to augment the response
  4. Systematic desensitization is the psychotherapy of choice

Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. b & c

 

Explanation:


The patient’s behavior of frequently checking locked doors is characteristic of OCD. The correct defense mechanisms commonly involved in OCD include isolation, undoing, and reaction formation, rather than repression. The first-line treatment for OCD involves selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline, and citalopram. Risperidone may be added to treatment regimens in cases where SSRIs alone are insufficient. The preferred psychotherapy for OCD is exposure and response prevention (ERP), not systematic desensitization.

 

Other options:


Option A. a & b: Repression is not typically involved in OCD, making this option incorrect.
 

Option C. b, c & d: Systematic desensitization is not the recommended psychotherapy for OCD, so this option is partially incorrect.
 

Option D. a, b, c & d: This option is incorrect because it includes repression and systematic desensitization, neither of which are appropriate for OCD.

 

Educational Objective:
 

SSRIs are the first-line pharmacotherapy for OCD, and risperidone can be used as an adjunct in resistant cases. The primary psychotherapeutic approach should be exposure and response prevention rather than systematic desensitization

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? (INICET Nov 2022)

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

 

Explanation:

 

a. Low APGAR score: SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.

 

b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.

 

c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.

 

d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

choices.text: Endobronchial neoplasm
Bronchial asthma
Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

In patient 1, flow volume curve shows restrictive pattern, and it corresponds to myasthenia gravis.

 

The flow volume curve shown indicates a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by reduced lung volumes but relatively preserved flow rates, consistent with non-obstructive lung pathology. Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often affects the respiratory muscles leading to a restrictive ventilatory defect as depicted in the flow volume loop. This condition results from antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction between the nerve and muscle, leading to muscle weakness including the respiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Asthma would show an obstructive pattern characterized by decreased peak expiratory flow and difficulty exhaling, which is not observed in the given curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), would also exhibit an obstructive pattern with a "scooped out" appearance on the expiratory curve due to air trapping and reduced elastic recoil, which is not seen in the curve provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

 

OPTION B: Blackening of urine on standing is characteristic feature of alkaptonuria.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational objective:

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

questions.text: The drug that decreases the size of prostate is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Finasteride

 

Finasteride: It inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its active form, DHT (dihydrotestosterone), by acting as a competitive inhibitor of the 5-reductase enzyme. It has a long-term effect of reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation, which reduces the size of the prostate and improves urine flow.

 

Tamsulosin is a Selective α1A Antagonist which dilates prostatic urethra and hence produces immediate symptom relief in BPH. It has no effect on reducing size of the prostate.

 

Flutamide is a Androgen Receptor antagonist with no hormonal activity. It is used for the treatment of metastatic prostatic cancer in conjunction with GnRH agonists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist. It works by relaxing the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate. While it provides symptomatic relief for BPH, it does not reduce the size of the prostate.

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It has no effect on prostate size.

 

Option D. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. It does not reduce the size of the prostate but works by blocking the effects of androgens (male hormones).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride decreases the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), thereby reducing prostatic cell proliferation and improving urinary symptoms in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

choices.text: NRT completely eliminates the risk of nicotine addiction.
NRT is only available in gum and patch forms.
NRT helps relieve cravings by providing nicotine in safer forms than cigarettes.
NRT absorption is unaffected by the consumption of acidic beverages.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years visits his primary care physician seeking help to quit smoking. He has tried quitting multiple times but struggles with intense cravings and withdrawal symptoms. The physician suggests nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) as part of his smoking cessation plan. During the discussion, the patient asks about the effectiveness and considerations of NRT. Which statement is true regarding nicotine replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. NRT helps relieve cravings by providing nicotine in safer forms than cigarettes.

 

Explanation:

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective strategy for smoking cessation that provides nicotine in safer, controlled forms compared to tobacco products. NRT helps reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by substituting the nicotine obtained from smoking with forms that do not contain the harmful chemicals found in cigarettes. Available preparations include nicotine gum, lozenges, patches, sprays, and inhalers, which offer flexibility in tailoring the therapy to the individual's needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NRT completely eliminates the risk of nicotine addiction: NRT does not eliminate nicotine addiction but provides a safer way to manage nicotine dependence as part of a smoking cessation plan. It helps gradually reduce the need for nicotine over time but does not instantly end addiction.

 

Option B. NRT is only available in gum and patch forms: This statement is incorrect because NRT is available in various forms, including lozenges, sprays, and inhalers, in addition to gums and patches, offering multiple options to suit individual preferences and needs.

 

Option D. NRT absorption is unaffected by the consumption of acidic beverages: Nicotine absorption from gums and lozenges can be significantly affected by acidic beverages such as coffee, soda, and juice. It is recommended to avoid consuming these beverages shortly before or during the use of these forms of NRT to ensure optimal absorption.

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) helps alleviate cravings and withdrawal symptoms by providing nicotine in safer forms compared to smoking. Various NRT products, including gums, patches, lozenges, sprays, and inhalers, offer flexible options tailored to individual needs. It is important to avoid acidic beverages when using NRT gum or lozenges to ensure proper absorption and effectiveness.

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can occur in patients taking diuretics. Diuretics increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to its depletion. The triad of ECG changes associated with hypokalemia are distinctive and include:

 

  1. Flattening of T waves: This is often the earliest change observed in hypokalemia.
  2. Prominent U waves: These waves become more visible as the potassium levels drop further.
  3. ST depression: This can occur in more severe cases of hypokalemia.

 

These ECG changes are due to the altered repolarization of the heart muscle cells caused by low potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia, or high potassium levels, typically presents with different ECG changes, such as tall, peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, and possibly absent P waves. These findings are not consistent with the patient's ECG.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: While low magnesium can cause ECG changes and muscle weakness, the specific ECG findings in this case (flat T waves and prominent U waves) are more indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels do not typically cause specific ECG changes. Severe hypernatremia might cause cerebral edema and nonspecific T wave inversions, but it does not lead to the characteristic ECG findings seen with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is characterized by ECG changes such as flattened T waves, prominent U waves, and ST depression. It is commonly seen in patients on diuretics, and recognizing these ECG patterns is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Following a hysterectomy, the patient received morphine for pain management both during the post-operative period and while in the ward. The current symptoms include respiratory depression and constricted (pinpoint) pupils. What would be the recommended medication for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naloxone

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid poisoning due to morphine, for which IV Naloxone can be administered.
  • In Morphine poisoning, the patient usually present in comatose state with low BP and heart rate as μ-receptor causes depression of brain including cardiovascular center.

 

SYMPTOMS OF OPIOID POISONING

 

  • Coma, respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Bradypnea
  • Hypothermia

 

ANTAGONISTS

 

  • Naloxone - Short acting, given iv
  • Naltrexone - Long acting, given Orally
  • DOC for acute opioid poisoning → Naloxone
  • DOC for maintenance in opioid poisoning → Naltrexone
    • Naloxone is added to oral opioids to reduce addictive potential.
    • Naltrexone is used to decrease craving in alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine/Meperidine is a μ receptor agonist.

 

Option B. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. Used in cases of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Buprenorphine is a partial μ receptor agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptor. It has ceiling Effect on respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone is the drug of choice for treating acute opioid overdose, characterized by symptoms such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and coma. It acts rapidly to reverse the effects of opioids by competitively inhibiting their action at opioid receptors.

questions.text: A 60-year gentleman was referred from outside hospital to AIIMS ER after he developed sudden onset quadriparesis. In hospital patient was treated with 3%NaCl, Oral tolvaptan. Initial metabolic panel revealed Na: 115 mEq/L, K: 2.8 mEq/L, Cl: 85 mEq/L with normal TSH, CBC, RFT, LFT.  What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?  (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Previously called central pontine myelinolysis. It occurs due to rapid correction of Chronic Hyponatremia (>8 mg/dL).

 

Timing: 2-6 days after rapid correction.

 

Rx: Irreversible. Desmopressin clamp if overcorrection in q6h Na values.  

 

Mechanism:

 

1. In Hyponatremia

 

 

2. On sudden correction:

 

 

Risk factors:

 

  1. Serum sodium ≤ 105 mEq/L
  2. Concurrent hypokalemia
  3. Chronic excess alcohol intake
  4. Acute or chronic hepatic disease
  5. Malnourishment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain infarct: Not directly suggested by the rapid onset of symptoms following electrolyte correction.

 

Option B. Brainstem injury: Could be considered but is less likely without trauma or vascular insult history.

 

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Not applicable as the condition involves the rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia should be avoided to prevent the severe neurological complications associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome. Control and monitoring of serum sodium levels are crucial during treatment.

 

Reference - Harrison/Electrolytes/Chap 53

questions.text: Match the mode of inheritance with the disorder in the appropriate column: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

1. Autosomal Dominant -  D. Myotonia dystrophica

  • Autosomal dominant disorders are typically inherited from one affected parent. Myotonia dystrophica, characterized by muscle stiffness and other systemic symptoms, exhibits this pattern of inheritance.

 

2. X-Linked Recessive – A. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy

  • X-linked recessive disorders mainly affect males and are passed on by carrier mothers. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy, which leads to muscle degeneration and weakness, is a classic example.

 

3. Autosomal Recessive – C. Cystic fibrosis

  • Autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to pass on a faulty gene. Cystic fibrosis, which causes severe damage to the respiratory and digestive systems, is inherited this way.

 

4. Mitochondrial – B. Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (Leber's disease)

  • Mitochondrial diseases are inherited through mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically passed from mother to all offspring. Leber's disease leads to sudden vision loss primarily in young adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Each genetic disorder has a specific pattern of inheritance that affects its transmission and manifestation in individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an adverse effect seen after a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

Hypercalcemia is not an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion

 

The more common adverse effects are related to calcium and potassium imbalances, which can occur due to the nature of stored blood and the transfusion process.

 

  • Hypercalcemia refers to high levels of calcium in the blood.
  • This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia refers to low levels of calcium in the blood.

 

  • It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia is low levels of potassium in the blood.

 

  • It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because red blood cells, which are rich in potassium, are often stored in blood transfusion bags. When a large amount of blood is transfused, it can lead to an influx of potassium into the recipient's bloodstream.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is high levels of potassium in the blood.

 

  • This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion, as explained in option C. The transfusion of a large volume of blood can introduce excess potassium into the recipient's circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

 

The lethal triad of massive blood transfusion is acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy.

choices.text: Progressive supranuclear palsy
Multiple system atrophy

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits the neurology clinic with his daughter, who reports that her father has had gradual changes in his behavior and personality over the past year. He has become socially inappropriate, displays poor judgment, and has trouble managing his finances. Despite these changes, his memory seems relatively preserved. On examination, the patient has no significant motor symptoms such as tremors or gait disturbances. Neuroimaging shows marked atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be classified as a subcortical dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Pick’s disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pick’s disease, also known as frontotemporal dementia (FTD), is classified as a type of cortical dementia, not subcortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes, leading to significant changes in personality, behavior, and language, with early preservation of memory. Cortical dementias differ from subcortical dementias, which involve deeper brain structures such as the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and brainstem, and typically present with early motor symptoms and milder cognitive changes early in the disease. The absence of prominent motor symptoms and the pattern of frontal and temporal atrophy further distinguish Pick’s disease as cortical rather than subcortical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progressive supranuclear palsy: Progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by subcortical dementia, presenting with early motor symptoms, including gait instability, vertical gaze palsy, and bradykinesia, along with cognitive impairment. It affects subcortical structures, making it distinct from cortical dementias like Pick’s disease.

 

Option B. Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia often involves subcortical regions, particularly when caused by small vessel disease or lacunar infarcts affecting the white matter and basal ganglia. It commonly presents with motor symptoms such as gait disturbances and executive dysfunction, which are hallmarks of subcortical dementias.

 

Option C. Multiple system atrophy: Multiple system atrophy is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects subcortical structures, including the basal ganglia and cerebellum. It presents with a combination of autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and cerebellar ataxia, making it a classic example of subcortical dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical dementias, such as Pick’s disease, primarily affect the cerebral cortex, leading to prominent personality and behavioral changes, whereas subcortical dementias involve deeper brain structures like the basal ganglia and present with early motor symptoms and milder cognitive decline in the early stages. Recognizing these distinctions is essential for accurate diagnosis and management of various dementia syndromes.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bebtelovimab

 

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of Sickle cell anemia. Voxelotor, hydroxyurea and L-glutamine are used for treatment of sickle cell anemia whereas Bebtelovimab is not used in in this condition.
  • Bebtelovimab is a new monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of COVID-19. It works by binding to the spike protein of the COVID-19 virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voxelotor: Is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Improves fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and is the primary drug for controlling HbS in sickle cell disease. Thus, improving the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option D. L-glutamine: Is a naturally occurring amino acid with antioxidant properties. It increases the availability of reduced glutathione which may lessen oxidative damage in sickle red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bebtelovimab is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia; it is a monoclonal antibody used for COVID-19 treatment. In contrast, Voxelotor, Hydroxyurea, and L-glutamine are used in managing sickle cell anemia by improving hemoglobin function and reducing oxidative stress in red blood cells.

questions.text: The drug of choice for treating scrub typhus? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus, caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, is effectively treated with Doxycycline, which is considered the first-line treatment. Doxycycline is administered at a dosage of 100 mg twice daily for 7 to 14 days. It disrupts protein synthesis in the bacterium, which is crucial for its effectiveness against this intracellular pathogen.

 

In pregnancy/children- Azithromycin/ chloramphenicol preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: While it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, it is not the preferred treatment for scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Chloramphenicol: This is an alternative treatment option but is generally reserved for cases where doxycycline or azithromycin cannot be used.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a suitable alternative, especially in special populations such as pregnant women and children, where doxycycline is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxycycline is the first-choice medication for treating scrub typhus in adults and non-pregnant women, offering effective relief and eradication of the pathogen when taken for the recommended duration.

questions.text:
A baby is diagnosed with B cell leukemia. All of the following are good prognostic factors except: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Hyperdiploidy
  2. Age < 1 year
  3. t(9;22)
  4. t(4;11)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is a common type of leukemia in children. Prognostic factors play a crucial role in determining the treatment plan and overall outcomes for patients.

 

2. Age < 1 year: Age less than 1 year is considered a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. Infants with B-ALL typically have a higher risk of relapse and a poorer response to therapy.

 

3. t(9;22): This translocation involves the Philadelphia chromosome, which is generally associated with poor prognosis in B-ALL. It leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a marker of poor prognosis.

 

4. t(4;11): This translocation is associated with rearrangements of the MLL (Mixed-Lineage Leukemia) gene, which is a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. It is commonly seen in infants and is associated with a poor outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes) is actually a good prognostic factor in B-ALL. Children with hyperdiploid B-ALL generally have a better response to therapy and a higher overall survival rate.

 

Thus, the factors B (Age < 1 year), C (t(9;22)), and D (t(4;11)) are all poor prognostic indicators, and only A (Hyperdiploidy) is a good prognostic factor.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

 

In a patient with renal insufficiency and low urine output, the preferred antihypertensive medication would be one that is safe in renal failure.

 

Amlodipine is a good choice because it is a calcium channel blocker that does not affect renal function. Although it can cause pedal edema in some patients but the pedal edema which is given in the question seems to be due to renal insufficiency itself. The adverse effect of pedal edema does not make it contra-indicated for hypertension.  It also has a long duration of action and is well-tolerated in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor that can lead to severe hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with renal insufficiency. Hyperkalemia can exacerbate renal dysfunction and pose serious health risks, making aliskiren an unsuitable choice for this patient.

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic. Thiazide diuretics are typically ineffective in patients with significantly impaired renal function (e.g., low GFR) and can cause electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia and hyponatremia. Therefore, chlorthalidone is not recommended for patients with renal insufficiency and low urine output.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker used to lower blood pressure. However, it is not typically a first-line drug for hypertension due to its side effects, such as postural hypotension. Additionally, prazosin can cause fluid retention, which may worsen renal function in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amlodipine is the preferred antihypertensive medication for patients with renal insufficiency, as it effectively lowers blood pressure without negatively impacting renal function.

choices.text: Only 1 is correct.
1 & 2 are correct.
2 & 3 are correct.
1, 2 & 4 are correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Decrease in reduced glutathione
  2. Decreased NADPH
  3. Decreased lipid peroxidation
  4. Decreased RBC membrane damage
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 & 2 are correct.

 

 

 

1. Decrease in reduced glutathione:


This statement is correct. G6PD deficiency leads to reduced levels of NADPH, which is necessary to maintain GSH in its reduced form. Without sufficient GSH, RBCs are more susceptible to oxidative damage, which can lead to hemolysis.

 

2. Decreased NADPH:


This statement is also correct. G6PD deficiency directly results in decreased production of NADPH in the pentose phosphate pathway. NADPH is necessary for the regeneration of reduced glutathione, which protects cells from oxidative stress.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Decreased lipid peroxidation:


This statement is incorrect. In fact, G6PD deficiency leads to increased oxidative stress, which can result in increased lipid peroxidation, not a decrease. Lipid peroxidation damages cell membranes, contributing to RBC hemolysis.

 

4. Decreased RBC membrane damage:


This statement is incorrect. The decreased levels of reduced glutathione and increased oxidative stress lead to more, not less, RBC membrane damage. This damage makes the RBCs more prone to hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency leads to decreased levels of NADPH and reduced glutathione, which are essential for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1197

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ferroportin

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferriportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferriportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the blood and transports it to various tissues, particularly the bone marrow for erythropoiesis. Hepcidin does not bind to transferrin; instead, it regulates iron export through ferroportin.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is involved in the uptake of iron (in its ferrous form) from the lumen of the intestine into enterocytes. Hepcidin does not interact with DMT1; its regulatory effect occurs after iron has been absorbed into enterocytes, at the point of iron export into the bloodstream via ferroportin.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is the intracellular protein that stores iron in a soluble and non-toxic form. Hepcidin does not bind to ferritin directly. However, by reducing the expression of ferroportin, hepcidin indirectly increases the storage of iron within cells in the form of ferritin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepcidin regulates iron homeostasis by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation, which prevents iron export from enterocytes into the plasma and from macrophages.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1231

questions.text: Which of the following is a novel anti-depressant? (INICET Nov 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vilazodone

 

Vilazodone is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor as well as a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist. It is a new antidepressant. It does not have the side effect of erectile dysfunction.

 

Vortioxetine is another example of a novel antidepressant, that apart from being a SSRI, acts on multiple other receptors of serotonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Lurasidone, Asenapine and Pimavanserin are examples of atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option A. Lurasidone: This is an atypical antipsychotic, primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. While it can be used to treat depressive episodes in bipolar disorder, it is not primarily categorized as an antidepressant.

 

Option C. Asenapine: Asenapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is not classified as an antidepressant.

 

Option D. Pimavanserin: This is an atypical antipsychotic and inverse agonist and antagonist of the serotonin receptors. It is primarily used in the treatment of psychosis in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant with a dual mechanism of action, functioning as both an SSRI and a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist, making it effective for treating depression with fewer sexual side effects. Other Options listed are atypical antipsychotics and not classified as antidepressants.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute respiratory infection

 

Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Kartagener syndrome and C. Situs inversus: Kartagener syndrome also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome is due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of:

 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs inversus - Major visceral organs are reversed or mirrored from their normal positions
  • Bronchiectasis

 

Infertility is also seen in Kartagener syndrome but it is not a part of its triad.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

 

NOTE: Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis are two different genetic disorders that can affect fertility in different ways.

 

  • In men with Kartagener syndrome, the cilia in the sperm cells may be abnormal or immotile, which can result in reduced sperm count and motility, leading to male infertility. Women with Kartagener syndrome may have reduced fertility due to impaired ciliary function in the fallopian tubes, which can lead to difficulty in egg transport and fertilization.
  • In the reproductive system, CF can cause thick, sticky mucus to block the vas deferens in men, leading to infertility due to the absence of sperm in the ejaculate. Women with CF may have reduced fertility due to thick cervical mucus that can impede sperm transport or block the fallopian tubes, preventing fertilization.

 

Overall, both Kartagener syndrome and cystic fibrosis can lead to infertility, but the underlying mechanisms and specific impacts on fertility can differ between the two conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciliocytophthoria, the degeneration of ciliated cells, is typically seen in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1292

choices.text: Gradual onset and stable course
Acute onset with fluctuating course
Persistent memory loss with clear consciousness
Hallucinations without fluctuations in attention

questions.text: During morning rounds, a 78-year-old male patient who was admitted for a urinary tract infection becomes increasingly confused and disoriented. He frequently appears to be talking to unseen people and struggles to focus on questions asked by examining doctor. His symptoms further seems to be worsened and his attention varies throughout the day. Based on these observations, which of the following features is most indicative of delirium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Acute onset with fluctuating course

 

Explanation:

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often with variations in severity throughout the day. It is a common condition in hospitalized elderly patients, particularly those with underlying medical issues. Delirium presents with disturbances in attention, awareness, and cognition, with symptoms that can worsen in the evening, known as "sundowning." The hallmark of delirium is its rapid onset and fluctuation, distinguishing it from other conditions with more stable or progressive courses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradual onset and stable course: This description is more indicative of dementia, which has a slow, progressive onset and does not fluctuate significantly over short periods, unlike the acute and fluctuating nature of delirium.

 

Option C. Persistent memory loss with clear consciousness: This feature aligns more with dementia, where memory loss occurs without the fluctuating levels of consciousness and attention seen in delirium.

 

Option D. Hallucinations without fluctuations in attention: Hallucinations can occur in many psychiatric and neurological conditions, including dementia and primary psychotic disorders, but the absence of fluctuating attention makes this less characteristic of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is an acute-onset neurocognitive disorder characterized by fluctuating levels of consciousness, attention disturbances, and cognitive impairment. It often worsens in the evening, particularly in elderly patients with underlying medical conditions. Recognizing the fluctuating nature and acute onset of delirium is crucial for prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

A. Zinc chloride:

 

  • Mechanism: Irritant
  • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.

 

B. Chloral hydrate:

 

  • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.

 

C. Quinine:

 

  • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.

 

D. Potassium carbonate:

 

  • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E-FAST

 

Given the scenario described with the stab injury, bradycardia, hypotension, and clear lung fields on chest radiography, there's a concern for a potential cardiac injury and tamponade, and E-FAST would be the most rapid and effective tool to evaluate for these as well as other potential injuries.

 

E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. It is an ultrasound examination that is performed on trauma patients in the emergency department to identify any life-threatening conditions that need to be addressed immediately. The components of E-FAST include:

 

  1. Subxiphoid view: This assesses for pericardial effusion (fluid around the heart) which could indicate a cardiac tamponade.
  2. Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid (which could indicate internal bleeding) in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney).
  3. Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ) view: This assesses for free fluid in the splenorenal recess (the space between the spleen and the left kidney).
  4. Suprapubic view: This assesses for free fluid in the pelvis.
  5. Anterior Chest view: This is performed bilaterally to assess for pneumothorax (air in the pleural space that can cause lung collapse) or hemothorax (blood in the pleural space).

 

The "extended" in E-FAST refers to additional views which can be added depending on the patient's condition and the clinician's suspicion of injury. These may include views of the thoracic spine and the lung bases to look for signs of additional injury.

 

 

E-FAST: Given the patient's presentation with hypotension, this would be the most appropriate initial step to rapidly identify a life-threatening condition in an unstable patient, like cardiac tamponade, which can cause bradycardia and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tube thoracostomy: Also known as a chest tube placement, it is used to treat pneumothorax or hemothorax by draining air or blood from the pleural space. However, in this patient, the chest radiography showed clear lung fields, suggesting that he does not have a significant hemothorax or pneumothorax.

 

Option C. CECT chest: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the chest can provide detailed images of the chest's anatomy and may identify injuries to the thoracic structures. However, in an acutely unstable trauma patient, a CT scan is not the best initial test due to the time it takes to perform and the need to transport the patient to the scanner.

 

Option D. CECT abdomen: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen can identify injuries to the abdominal organs. However it will be avoided in an unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E-FAST is a rapid ultrasound examination used in trauma patients to assess for life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, hemothorax, and pneumothorax. It is the most appropriate initial step for an unstable patient with a stab injury, bradycardia, and hypotension, given its ability to quickly provide critical information needed for immediate management.

questions.text: All are features of Zika Fever except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petechial rash

 

Petechial rash is not a feature of Zika Virus. Though petechia may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of Dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash is not typically associated with Zika virus infection. It is more commonly associated with Dengue fever, where petechiae (small red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin) are a common feature.

 

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

 

The complications of Zika virus are:

 

  • Gullian Barre Syndrome
  • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guillain-Barre syndrome: Zika virus has been linked to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can cause severe muscle weakness and even paralysis.

 

Option C. Fever with arthritis: Fever with arthritis or arthralgia is a common feature of Zika virus infection.

 

Option D. Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (red eyes) is a frequent symptom of Zika virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika fever typically presents with a maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, fever, and arthralgia, and it can be complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome. Petechial rash is not a common feature and is more indicative of Dengue fever.

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid
Hemolytic anemia is a feature
B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

 

Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytes) in the bone marrow and blood due to impaired DNA synthesis. Folate is crucial for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, the building blocks of DNA, which is why DNA synthesis is directly affected.

 

  • High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels increase because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal, which helps differentiate folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, where methylmalonic acid levels are elevated.
  • B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is recommended because both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies can lead to similar hematologic manifestations, like megaloblastic anemia. However, treating a patient with folic acid alone when they have an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency can mask the hematologic symptoms while allowing neurological damage to progress. Therefore, it is safer to supplement both B12 and folate unless B12 deficiency has been ruled out.
  • Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: Folate is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, which are necessary for DNA replication. Specifically, folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units during the synthesis of these nucleotides. In its absence, DNA synthesis is impaired, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: This statement is true and correctly describes the biochemical changes in folate deficiency.

 

Option C. B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is a true statement and an important clinical practice to avoid masking B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: This statement is true because folate is directly involved in nucleotide synthesis, which is critical for DNA replication and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

choices.text: Examination in chief

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading questions are not allowed in all of the following except? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross examination

 

In Cross examination, leading questions are allowed to challenge the witness's testimony and credibility.

 

Leading Question:
