  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by lawyer, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Re-examination: Follow-up questioning by the party who called the witness, after cross-examination. In this leading questions are not allowed to ensure the witness's own account is clarified or points raised during cross-examination are rebutted without leading the witness.

 

Option C. Examination in Chief: The initial questioning of a witness by the party who called them. Leading questions are not permitted to ensure the witness's testimony is their own and not influenced by the questioner.

 

Option D. Dying Declaration: A statement made by a person who believes they are about to die, concerning the cause or circumstances of their death. Leading questions are not allowed to ensure the statement is voluntary and not influenced, preserving its reliability.

 

Educational Objective

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in:

 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in:

 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.

 

 

FABER position of limb after dislocation

 

  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • It is less common than posterior dislocation
  • It is divided into various types according to the position assumed by the femoral head: 
    • Pubic
    • Obturator
    • Perineal
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture at the affected hip, with restriction of movement.
    • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).
       
  • Imaging Findings
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • An anterior dislocation usually can be reduced without surgery by pulling longitudinally on the thigh.
    • If the dislocation cannot be reduced by these maneuvers, open reduction is performed.
       
  • Complication: 
    • Avascular necrosis.
    • Because of their anterior relationship to the hip, the femoral vessels and nerve may be injured, especially with pubic dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of hip. The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. It is more common (90%). The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed in motor accidents. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

In plain radiograph, the femoral head is out of the acetabulum.

 

 

The thigh is internally rotated so, the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken. In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. Open reduction may be required in cases where closed reduction fails, if there is intra-articular loose fragment, and if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Complications include injury to the sciatic nerve, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, osteoarthritis, myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of hip. Inferior dislocation of hip or luxatio erecta femoris is the rarest among all types of hip dislocation. It can be caused by a severe trauma to the hip. Most of the reported cases involve the pediatric age group. There are two types of inferior hip dislocation; ischial type and obturator type. In the obturator type, when a force is applied to femur while the hip joint is in abduction and flexion, the femoral head dislocates anteriorly and inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In the ischial type, a force is applied to femur while hip and knee joints are in hyperflexion without abduction or external rotation. The femoral head dislocates inferiorly next to the ischium. The ischial type is more common than the obturator type.

 

 

Option D. Central dislocation of hip. A central dislocation involves the femoral head being forced downward. Acetabular fractures with central hip dislocation result from direct axial loading through the greater trochanter in abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

 

Explanation

 

Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.

 

Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.

 

Option B. Coagulation factors: Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.

 

Option C. Acute phase proteins: Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

 

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

choices.text: Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text: Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below. HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc (total) positive, Anti-HDV (total) positive. Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies

 

To differentiate between HDV co-infection and superinfection, it is essential to understand the nature of these infections:

 

  • Co-infection occurs when a patient acquires both acute HBV and acute HDV simultaneously. The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.
  • Superinfection occurs when a patient with chronic HBV infection acquires an acute HDV infection. In this scenario, the patient has markers of chronic HBV (like Anti-HBc IgG antibodies) along with markers of acute HDV infection.

 

The Anti-HBc IgM antibodies are indicative of an acute HBV infection and are useful for diagnosing co-infection because they show that the HBV infection is recent, which aligns with the scenario of both HBV and HDV being acquired simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: This can be present in both co-infection and superinfection and does not specifically differentiate between the two.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: These antibodies can be present in both co-infection and superinfection as they indicate an acute HDV infection. Therefore, they are not useful in differentiating between the two conditions.

 

Option D. Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies: This indicates a past or chronic HBV infection. The presence of Anti-HBc IgG is more consistent with superinfection rather than co-infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection because it indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image are:

 

Option A. 1- Rectus femoris

Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis

Option C. 3- Adductor longus

Option D. 4- Sartorius

 

Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.

 

The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.

 

The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: Which hormone crosses the plasma membrane for its action? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroxine

 

Thyroxine crosses the plasma membrane for its action.

 

The thyroid hormone receptors are either attached to the DNA genetic strands or located in proximity to them. The thyroid hormone receptor usually forms a heterodimer with retinoid X receptor (RXR) at specific thyroid hormone response elements on the DNA. On binding with thyroid hormone, the receptors become activated and initiate the transcription process. Then large numbers of different types of messenger RNA are formed, followed within another few minutes or hours by RNA translation on the cytoplasmic ribosomes to form hundreds of new intracellular proteins.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Epinephrine: Incorrect. Epinephrine is a catecholamine that acts on cell surface receptors (adrenergic receptors) and does not cross the plasma membrane to exert its effects.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Incorrect. Glucagon is a peptide hormone that binds to receptors on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin is a peptide hormone that binds to its receptor on the cell surface and does not cross the plasma membrane.

 

Educational objective

 

Thyroxine (T4) crosses the plasma membrane and binds to intracellular receptors to exert its effects, initiating transcription and subsequent protein synthesis.

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

choices.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
Decreased release of 02
It has less P50
It is less acidic

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

 

Explanation

 

The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.

 

The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.

 

In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.

 

Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased release of O2: Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.

 

Option C. It has less P50: Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.

 

Option D. It is less acidic: Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding De Quervain's tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It affects APL and EPB

 

De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendons. These tendons run side by side and are located on the radial side of the wrist, traveling through a tunnel (sheath) that can become narrowed due to the inflammation, causing pain especially with thumb and wrist movement.

 

 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It's the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fingers are held in mild extension: This statement is not typically associated with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Instead, the thumb is often held in a position of abduction away from the hand to minimize pain. The condition mainly affects the tendons and their sheaths at the base of the thumb, not the fingers.

 

Option C. Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis primarily affects the base of the thumb. While pain can radiate and might be felt in the nearby areas, including the forearm or even the index finger, the primary site of involvement is the tendons at the thumb's base, not the index finger itself.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgery: While surgery can be an option for De Quervain's tenosynovitis, it is generally considered when conservative treatments fail. Most cases of De Quervain's can be treated conservatively with methods such as: Rest and immobilization using splints, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation , Corticosteroid injections into the tendon sheath to reduce inflammation and Physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graph D

 

Explanation:

 

The normal response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is depicted by Graph D. During an OGTT, a patient ingests a specified amount of glucose (commonly 75 grams), and blood glucose levels are measured at intervals to evaluate how well the body handles glucose. In a normal response:

 

  • Blood glucose levels rise to a peak within 1 hour after ingestion.
  • Glucose levels then decline and return to baseline by 2 hours.
  • The glucose levels do not exceed the renal threshold at any point during the test.

 

This pattern reflects the body's effective regulation of blood glucose levels and the normal function of insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graph A: Graph A might depict an abnormal glucose tolerance curve, such as one seen in impaired glucose tolerance or gestational diabetes, where glucose levels remain elevated for a prolonged period or fail to return to baseline.

 

Option B. Graph B: Graph B could show a response with an abnormal peak or delayed return to baseline, indicative of glucose intolerance or a diagnostic criterion for diabetes mellitus.

 

Option C. Graph C: Graph C might represent an exaggerated glucose peak or prolonged elevated glucose levels, suggesting a pathological glucose tolerance response consistent with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal OGTT response features a peak in blood glucose levels within 1 hour, followed by a return to baseline levels within 2 hours, without exceeding the renal threshold.

 

Ref: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301045468_VARIANTS_OF_ORAL_GLUCOSE_TOLERANCE_TEST_OGTT_CURVE_IN_GESTATIONAL_DIABETES_MELLITUS_GDM

questions.text: Which of the following topical antifungal has both anti- inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sertaconazole

 

Sertaconazole has both anti-inflammatory effects and anti-pruritic action. It is used to treat dermatophytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that also has anti-androgenic effects. However, it does not possess notable anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic properties.

 

Option C. Luliconazole: Luliconazole is effective against dermatophytes and yeasts, but it does not have significant anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic actions.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is mainly used to treat dermatophytosis. It does not have substantial anti-inflammatory or anti-pruritic effects.

 

Educational Objective:
